expanded_description: This section introduces physics as the science that helps us understand how things move, why things fall, and how energy works in our everyday world.

core_concept.principle: Physics helps us understand the world around us by studying matter, energy, and how they interact.
core_concept.explanation: Physics explains everyday things like why balls bounce, how cars move, and why we need seatbelts. It uses experiments and math to find patterns in nature.

sections.introduction: Physics is all around us! It helps explain why things happen the way they do in our daily lives.

key_concept.definition: Physics is the study of matter (stuff), energy (what makes things happen), and how they work together.
key_concept.context: Physics helps us understand everything from sports to music to how our phones work.

classifications.behavior: Physics principles explain why everyday things work the way they do

examples.explanation:
Basketball: Why the ball follows a curved path when you shoot
Soccer: Why the ball spins when you kick it
Swimming: Why you can float in water
Skateboarding: Why you keep moving when you stop pushing

Cooking: Why water boils at 100°C
Lighting: Why light bulbs get hot
Sound: Why you can hear through walls
Gravity: Why things fall when you drop them

key_concept.definition: Scientists use a step-by-step method to answer questions about how the world works.
key_concept.context: This method helps scientists make sure their answers are correct and reliable.

classifications.value: A simple way to investigate questions
classifications.behavior: Scientists follow steps to make sure they find good answers to their questions

examples.explanation:
Question: Which paper airplane design flies farthest?
Guess: The longer, thinner design will fly farther
Test: Make different designs and measure how far they fly
Result: Some designs really do fly farther than others

Question: Do different balls bounce to the same height?
Guess: Heavier balls will bounce higher
Test: Drop different balls from the same height and measure
Result: Some balls are much bouncier than others

classifications.value: How we measure the world around us
classifications.behavior: Scientists use standard units to measure things so everyone understands the results

examples.explanation:
Length: Meters (height of a door is about 2 meters)
Time: Seconds (a heartbeat is about 1 second)
Mass: Kilograms (a textbook is about 1 kilogram)
Temperature: Celsius (water freezes at 0°C, boils at 100°C)

Building: Need exact measurements for buildings to be safe
Cooking: Need exact measurements for recipes to work
Sports: Need exact timing for races and games
Weather: Need exact temperatures for weather forecasts

classifications.value: How to stay safe when doing experiments
classifications.behavior: Safety rules help prevent accidents and make sure everyone can learn safely

examples.explanation:
Wear safety glasses when needed
Tie back long hair
No running in the lab
Clean up spills immediately
Know where emergency equipment is located

Keep water away from electrical equipment
Don't touch outlets with wet hands
Use equipment properly
Tell teacher if something seems wrong

classifications.value: Tools we use to measure and experiment
classifications.behavior: Different tools help us measure different things accurately

examples.explanation:
Ruler: Measures length in centimeters
Stopwatch: Measures time in seconds
Thermometer: Measures temperature
Scale: Measures weight or mass

Magnifying glass: Makes small things look bigger
Meter stick: Measures longer distances
Spring scale: Measures how hard something pulls
Protractor: Measures angles

classifications.value: How to record your experiments and findings
classifications.behavior: Good records help you remember what you did and share your discoveries with others

examples.explanation:
Date and time of experiment
Materials you used
Steps you followed
Measurements you took
What you observed
What you learned

Bar graphs: Compare different things (like different ball bounce heights)
Line graphs: Show changes over time (like temperature during the day)
Always include: Title, labels, units
Keep it neat and easy to read

summary: Physics helps us understand how things work in our everyday world. Scientists use the scientific method to ask questions and find answers through experiments. We measure things using standard units like meters and seconds. Safety is very important when doing experiments. We use simple tools like rulers and stopwatches to make measurements. Keeping good records in a science journal helps us remember what we learned and share our discoveries with others.
